Symbolic Victory
Regretfully, military recruiting should be reinstated
on campus. It is fine to say that the government's interference with the internal affairs of a university is
deplorable, but when you get right down to it, banning
military recruiting on campus is simply not worth the
loss in jobs and money.
One hundred persons--from secretaries to researchers--would lose their jobs if Department of Defense
Funds were curtailed. The work of 100 more professors
and graduate students would also be placed in jeopardy.
Most of the nearly $3 million in defense contracts and
grants allocated to the Baltimore campuses are not
remotely connected to war research. Much of the work
being done for DOD, particularly on the East Baltimore
campuses,could just as conceivably be done for Health,
Education and Welfare. The fact is that DOD has
branched out far beyond pure military concerns. None
of the work is classified. In many instances, professors
simply went to DOD for funds because money was not
available elsewhere.
Most of the people who would suffer from the DOD
cutback were never represented in Homewood's
referendum last spring. Not only were the nonprofessional workers on campus not represented, but
the Schools of Medicine and Hygiene were involved in
the question.
Military recruiting was--and remains--at best a
symbolic issue and its banishment yielded only a
symbolic victory. A few recruiters on campus didn't
make any difference to the effectiveness of the Pentagon's war machine, and had little practical effect on
the lives of most members of the University.
But as President Gordon said in his letter to the Deans
earlier this week, the issue has changed character in the
light of new and unavoidable facts.

The Gut Issue
Of course the President and Board of Trustees will
simply reverse Homewood's referendum of last spring
to maintain the flow of DOD money. But such
pragmatism should just be the start of a major
reassessment of Hopkins ties with the government.

Dependence on DOD
By JOHN S. MANN
There is an atmosphere of hysteria
developing about the D.O.D. contracts. One
component of it is an entrenchment of
strongly punitive and vindictive feelings
toward the anti-war, anti-military
movement on campus, whic!", it is claimed,
is responsible for the mess we are in.
Another component is a panicky feeling that
we are helpless in the tightening grip of
federal control of higher education.
A third component of the hysteria is the
view that the university is doomed to
crumble in the predictable forthcoming
struggle among the various factions. I
should like to ask that we take a calmer,
more long-term, and less self-centered view
of the situation.
In the years since W.W.II, the academic
professions have enjoyed a growth in
prestige, power, influence, and consumption
of capital goods which is unprecedented in
American History. They have also enjoyed
an amazing growth in sheer numbers. These
two sorts of growth are dangerous to the
most stalwart of enterprises.
But take something as fragile as a
dedication to knowledge, and expose it to the
temptations of power and prestige in exchange for "only very minor" compromises-so minor, let us say, as selection of a
problem to be studied--and simultaneously
expose it to a massive influx of aspiring
young professionals in whose training a
personal dedication to knowing becomes
necessarily a decreasingly important
criterion for success, and you have the
makings of a major force.
Hook, Line and Sinker
Now I don't know very many individual
faculty people whose personal motives I
would question. Still, collectively there seems
to have been an agreement at least to
overlook certain prices we've been paying
for success. Then the agreement became a
habit, and then the habit became the very air
we breathe, so like the fish who only learns
that he lives in water upon being yanked by
the hook up into the air, we seem unable to
recognize the characteristics of the environment that sustains as under the impact
of anything less than a disaster.
Now the hook and line we are caught upon
is our collective decision to ban military
recruitment at the Homewood campus of
Hopkins. But this hook and line did not
create the situation of which it has made us
aware. It is only in combination with subsequent events that the hook and line turns
out to have called our attention to the fact
that we are living in muddy water.
Congress has yanked the line, and we
suddenly, gaspingly, realize that we have
conditioned ourselves to accept dependence,
for our survival, upon the Department of
Defense.
Ethical Questions
There are two ethical questions here, and
some practical ones, and none of them have
a great deal to do with the view that all the
trouble is caused by the "movement"
constituency.
1. Given the role that the U.S.D.O.D. is
currently playing or has recently played in
Viet-Nam, Cambodia, Laos, Thailand,
Guatemala, Chile, Brazil, Greece, Spain,
and elsewhere, is it ethically appropriate for
the Johns Hopkins University to make its
facilities available for the hiring of recruits?
2. Given the delicate conditions required to
sustain honest intellectual inquiry, is it
reasonable for a community of scholars to
allow itself to become financially dependent
upon an institution whose interests, fundamentally, are quite different from, and
even upon occasion inconsistent with, the
scholar's fundamental interest in pursuit of
truth?

Now my answer to both of these ethical
questions is an unqualified no. It is intolerable that a University dedicated to
scholarship should be financially dependent
upon the Department .of Defense.
Practical Question
A practical question follows: what options
are open to us? There are two of them,
essentially, and they are simple, clear-cut,
and decisive in terms of establishing what
sort of a place Hopkins is to be.
1. We reverse the ban on military
recruiting and thereby simultaneously
confirm our dependent relation to the D.O.D.
and our priorities regarding independence,
scholarship, moral commitment and money.
2. We confirm the ban on military
recruiting and thereby simultaneously
terminate our dependent relation to D.O.D.
and, again, assert our priorities with respect
to independence, scholarship, moral commitment and money.
Now some further questions follow. The
main one is what happens to us under each of
the two alternatives.
If we choose alternative one, then in my
judgment this puts to rest permanently the
University's claim and especially the
faculty's claim to special privilege by virtue
, of commitment to high ends. We become just
regular people making a buck, neither more
nor less exalted (excepting the extremes to
which our pretensions have gone) than other
production workers in the American
Economy.
No More Noble Traditions
Under these conditions, there is an implicit
confession that there is no longer any noble
liberal tradition of scholarship to protect
here at Hopkins--only the special interests of
a rather self-indulgent group of skilled
workers. From my view, these interests are
more readily expendable, more justifiably
subject to attack when they are in conflict
with other interests, than would be an institution seeking to protect a "noble tradition
of liberal scholarship," and my actions will
be in accordance with this view.
On the other hand, if we choose alternative
two, we lose 3 million dollars. Now how
important, in the eye of the community of
scholars, is that 3 million dollars, and what
recourse do we have to compensate the loss?
There are some complicated questions involved here that I have no answers to. As far
as my own field goes, which is the study of
education, it is very clear to me that many of
the most vitally important questions can be
studied without large expenditures, and that
in fact the, well-known expensive studies
have produced only very little by way of
either direct application to practice or
durable contribution to fundamental
knowledge.
Studies Can Wait
Certainly it is desirable to do some expensive studies, but by and large no such
studies are so pressingly important that they
can't be deferred until such a time that they
can be conducted without selling freedom of
inquiry to the D.O.D. I understand that the
situation is difficult, say, in physics. But
even there, at least one noble soul early in
his career committed himself explicitly to
work on problems that don't require expensive machinery, and he has survived
handsomely.
I don't really know how much we need the
3 million for research purposes, but let us
look at the other question--what recourse do
we have if we refuse to comply with D.O.D.

Dependence on DOD
By JOHN S. MANN
There is an atmosphere of hysteria
developing about the D.O.D. contracts. One
component of it is an entrenchment of
strongly punitive and vindictive feelings
toward the anti-war, anti-military
movement on campus, whic!", it is claimed,
is responsible for the mess we are in.
Another component is a panicky feeling that
we are helpless in the tightening grip of
federal control of higher education.
A third component of the hysteria is the
view that the university is doomed to
crumble in the predictable forthcoming
struggle among the various factions. I
should like to ask that we take a calmer,
more long-term, and less self-centered view
of the situation.
In the years since W.W.II, the academic
professions have enjoyed a growth in
prestige, power, influence, and consumption
of capital goods which is unprecedented in
American History. They have also enjoyed
an amazing growth in sheer numbers. These
two sorts of growth are dangerous to the
most stalwart of enterprises.
But take something as fragile as a
dedication to knowledge, and expose it to the
temptations of power and prestige in exchange for "only very minor" compromises-so minor, let us say, as selection of a
problem to be studied--and simultaneously
expose it to a massive influx of aspiring
young professionals in whose training a
personal dedication to knowing becomes
necessarily a decreasingly important
criterion for success, and you have the
makings of a major force.
Hook, Line and Sinker
Now I don't know very many individual
faculty people whose personal motives I
would question. Still, collectively there seems
to have been an agreement at least to
overlook certain prices we've been paying
for success. Then the agreement became a
habit, and then the habit became the very air
we breathe, so like the fish who only learns
that he lives in water upon being yanked by
the hook up into the air, we seem unable to
recognize the characteristics of the environment that sustains as under the impact
of anything less than a disaster.
Now the hook and line we are caught upon
is our collective decision to ban military
recruitment at the Homewood campus of
Hopkins. But this hook and line did not
create the situation of which it has made us
aware. It is only in combination with subsequent events that the hook and line turns
out to have called our attention to the fact
that we are living in muddy water.
Congress has yanked the line, and we
suddenly, gaspingly, realize that we have
conditioned ourselves to accept dependence,
for our survival, upon the Department of
Defense.
Ethical Questions
There are two ethical questions here, and
some practical ones, and none of them have
a great deal to do with the view that all the
trouble is caused by the "movement"
constituency.
1. Given the role that the U.S.D.O.D. is
currently playing or has recently played in
Viet-Nam, Cambodia, Laos, Thailand,
Guatemala, Chile, Brazil, Greece, Spain,
and elsewhere, is it ethically appropriate for
the Johns Hopkins University to make its
facilities available for the hiring of recruits?
2. Given the delicate conditions required to
sustain honest intellectual inquiry, is it
reasonable for a community of scholars to
allow itself to become financially dependent
upon an institution whose interests, fundamentally, are quite different from, and
even upon occasion inconsistent with, the
scholar's fundamental interest in pursuit of
truth?

Now my answer to both of these ethical
questions is an unqualified no. It is intolerable that a University dedicated to
scholarship should be financially dependent
upon the Department .of Defense.
Practical Question
A practical question follows: what options
are open to us? There are two of them,
essentially, and they are simple, clear-cut,
and decisive in terms of establishing what
sort of a place Hopkins is to be.
1. We reverse the ban on military
recruiting and thereby simultaneously
confirm our dependent relation to the D.O.D.
and our priorities regarding independence,
scholarship, moral commitment and money.
2. We confirm the ban on military
recruiting and thereby simultaneously
terminate our dependent relation to D.O.D.
and, again, assert our priorities with respect
to independence, scholarship, moral commitment and money.
Now some further questions follow. The
main one is what happens to us under each of
the two alternatives.
If we choose alternative one, then in my
judgment this puts to rest permanently the
University's claim and especially the
faculty's claim to special privilege by virtue
, of commitment to high ends. We become just
regular people making a buck, neither more
nor less exalted (excepting the extremes to
which our pretensions have gone) than other
production workers in the American
Economy.
No More Noble Traditions
Under these conditions, there is an implicit
confession that there is no longer any noble
liberal tradition of scholarship to protect
here at Hopkins--only the special interests of
a rather self-indulgent group of skilled
workers. From my view, these interests are
more readily expendable, more justifiably
subject to attack when they are in conflict
with other interests, than would be an institution seeking to protect a "noble tradition
of liberal scholarship," and my actions will
be in accordance with this view.
On the other hand, if we choose alternative
two, we lose 3 million dollars. Now how
important, in the eye of the community of
scholars, is that 3 million dollars, and what
recourse do we have to compensate the loss?
There are some complicated questions involved here that I have no answers to. As far
as my own field goes, which is the study of
education, it is very clear to me that many of
the most vitally important questions can be
studied without large expenditures, and that
in fact the, well-known expensive studies
have produced only very little by way of
either direct application to practice or
durable contribution to fundamental
knowledge.
Studies Can Wait
Certainly it is desirable to do some expensive studies, but by and large no such
studies are so pressingly important that they
can't be deferred until such a time that they
can be conducted without selling freedom of
inquiry to the D.O.D. I understand that the
situation is difficult, say, in physics. But
even there, at least one noble soul early in
his career committed himself explicitly to
work on problems that don't require expensive machinery, and he has survived
handsomely.
I don't really know how much we need the
3 million for research purposes, but let us
look at the other question--what recourse do
we have if we refuse to comply with D.O.D.
